page.title: 11Eartham Church St.Margaret's
page.content: The tiny village church of St. Margaret's at Eartham shares its vicar with the neighbouring village of Slindon. The flint building,although heavily restored in 1869,still retains a good deal of work dating from the early 12th century. The west wall of the nave is from this period, although the porch is modern. Modern windows in the north wall of the nave disguise the fact that this is also 12th century. Although the church is so small,it has always been a popular place of worship. We learn from early wills that money was left so that lights would be maintained before the High Altar and in the chapels,and that testators left sheep and cows whose produce and progeny would also pay for these lights to be kept burning and prayers would be said for the dead.
